Regional Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number 42053 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
November 2008 
 
 
 
 
 
Quantifying the Costs and Benefits of Regional 
Economic Integration in Asia

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ABMI  –  Asian Bond Markets Initiative 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ADBI  –  Asian Development Bank Institute 
AFTA  –  ASEAN Free Trade Area 
ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance 
(RDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy

NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Head               J.W. Lee, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
 
Director             S. Madhur, OREI 
 
 
 
Team leader  H.C. Tang, Economist, OREI 
 
Team members  J. Menon, Principal Economist, OREI 
 
J. Duque-Comia, Economics Officer, OREI

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Recently,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  published  three  books  on  Asian 
regional economic integration: in 2004, the two-volume Monetary and Financial Integration in 
East Asia; in 2005, Asian Economic Cooperation and Integration: Progress, Prospects and 
Challenges; and more recently in 2008, Emerging Asian Regionalism: A Partnership of Shared 
Prosperity.1 In essence, the focus of these publications was to take stock and identify the way 
forward.  Apart  from  some  short-term  caveats,  closer  regional  cooperation  was  viewed  as 
inevitable and, through regional cooperation, the region would as a whole benefit and global 
welfare would also improve.  
 
2.  This proposed project will focus on whether quantifiable results can be substantiated in 
the areas of trade and investment, money and finance, and infrastructure.2 The project is 
envisaged to be a key reference of current consensus and differences in the debate of regional 
economic integration, an area some Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member 
countries have requested ADB to pursue. Policy makers will gain from having a more objective 
and complete diagnosis of initiatives that promote regional economic integration and are also 
beneficial to their own countries. Successful completion of this project represents a further step 
in meeting the long-term impact of ADB's Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy.3 It will 
also further enhance ADB’s comparative strength in regional cooperation and integration as 
identified in its long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020).4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The  emerging  Asian  regionalism  currently  being  witnessed  is  largely  a  recent 
phenomenon in response to: (i) the contagious impacts of the 1997 Asian financial crisis on 
regional economies; (ii) the growing significance of the People's Republic of China (PRC) and 
India  as  competitors  and  markets  for  other  regional  economies;  and  (iii)  the  increased 
regionalism  in  other  parts  of  the  world,  notably  Europe.  In  fact,  the  increased  regional 
integration that has been highlighted is mainly concerned with intraregional trade, which has 
been  driven  not  by  formal  trade  agreements  but  rather  by  regional  production  networks, 
especially the relocation of Japanese corporations to many ASEAN countries in the early 1980s. 
In the 1990s, the emergence of the PRC as a production hub of the world and source of exports 
for ASEAN countries further strengthened intraregional trade flows and deepened its tie with the 
international production chain. Amid these developments, trade liberalizations under the ASEAN 
Free Trade Area (AFTA) were only formalized in 1992. Hence, for these countries, their strong 
growth performance even post-1992 cannot be easily ascribed to the AFTA alone.  
 
4.  Also, free trade agreements (FTAs) may not benefit countries equally. Countries in an 
FTA are generally found to benefit from higher growth, however other studies do not support a 
robust relationship between free trade and economic growth.5 Moreover, countries outside the

FTA tend to lose out.6 On the other hand, it would seem that smaller countries tend to benefit 
from  trade  liberalizations  through  wider  market  access.  However,  facts  show  that  bigger 
countries with better initial conditions and better absorptive capacities do better.7 In addition, 
empirical evidence does not convincingly show a convergence between income levels of poorer 
and richer member countries in all FTAs. The evidence for an East Asian FTA is found to be 
particularly weak.8  
 
5.  Another area where differing views exist is the nexus between foreign direct investment 
(FDI) and economic growth. FDI is theorized to expand growth via improvements in technology, 
efficiency,  and  productivity  coming  from  the  more  advanced  technology  and  management 
practices of foreign firms. In general, empirical evidence from developed countries shows that 
the spillover effects from FDI to the domestic firms is positive, but for developing countries the 
evidence is mixed, showing a positive or generally limited or no efficiency spillovers.9 At the 
macro level, the evidence between FDI and growth is generally positive, except under certain 
conditions, such as when the receiving countries are higher-income developing countries with 
adequate absorptive capacity (such as the necessary human capital) and an export-promoting 
regime. Yet some researchers argue that FDI does not drive growth but instead is driven by 
growth  –  more  productive  and  more  rapidly  expanding  economies  tend  to  attract 
multinationals.10 Also, domestic firms in the export sector are more efficient, not because of the 
presence of the foreign firms but because, in the face of international competition, they have to 
be.  
 
6.  Large infrastructure projects are intrinsically costly and risky for individual countries to 
undertake, and this is where regional pooling of resources becomes important. In many parts of 
the Asia and Pacific region, severe bottlenecks in road transportation, ports, energy, and water 
have not only increased the cost of doing business, but most probably held growth back.11 
Limited empirical evidence generally supports the finding that cross-border infrastructure spurs 
growth  and  reduces  poverty.12 In  ADB, there  are  at  least  two  ongoing  initiatives  to  better 
understand the impact of cross-border infrastructure. The ADB and Asian Development Bank 
Institute (ADBI) Flagship Study on Infrastructure and Regional Cooperation will have papers 
examining, among other issues, the socioeconomic impacts of transport infrastructure projects 
in the Greater Mekong Subregion and South Asia, and pipeline infrastructure projects in Central 
Asia.13 These will be macro-level studies employing computable general equilibrium models. In

7.  Small and open economies often prefer a fixed exchange rate system for fear that 
exchange  rate  variability  creates  uncertainty  and  thus  discourages  international  trade  and 
investment. Despite the perceived importance of exchange rate regimes to long-term growth 
and economic stability, the empirical evidence is rather inconclusive and, at best, the growth 
performance  of  a fixed  exchange  rate regime  is  no  worse  than  that  of  a floating regime. 
Empirical studies by Jeffrey Frankel and his colleagues tend to provide more favorable results – 
the adoption of the euro or the US dollar appears to contribute positively towards trade and 
output growth.15 Others, such as Kenneth Rogoff, however, have argued that the magnitude 
does not appear to be large, and that the trade expansion effects may not have any great 
impact on welfare and they depend on a country’s level of financial development.16 
 
8.  Most  studies  based  on  the  optimum  currency  area  criteria  do  not  support  the 
establishment  of  an  overarching  monetary  union  for  all  Asian  countries,  though  a  smaller 
grouping of countries may not be ruled out.17 In addition, due to diverse political aspirations and 
wide disparity in regional economic development, there is little support among Asian policy 
makers for any form of monetary policy coordination at this stage.18 Studies looking at the whole 
variety of currency arrangements often do not support Asia follow any of these paths, yet there 
is a growing consensus that deeper financial integration should be actively pursued to propel 
real integration to the next stage (footnote 1). The question then is, with the nature of financial 
integration currently in progress and planned (such as those in the Asian Bond Market Initiative 
[ABMI] and the Executives’ Meeting of East Asia-Pacific Central Banks), whether these have 
measurable  and  important  contributions  to  greater  trade  integration  and  financial  stability 
(paragraph 9). This is all the more salient given the likely absence of any formal exchange rate 
or monetary arrangements in the foreseeable future. That said, it is still interesting to examine 
(given increased trade interdependence between countries) whether potential gains can be 
achieved through greater regional monetary policy coordination between trading countries. That 
is, would the benefits of having a single monetary union in terms of facilitating trade and 
investment outweigh the loss of independent monetary policy in insulating the effects of foreign 
disturbances on domestic employment and output? 
 
9.  Deeper financial integration leads to greater financial stability, as architects of financial 
reforms after the 1997 Asian financial crisis espouse. Undertakings of ABMI are said to bring 
myriad benefits in the form of recycling of regional savings for regional investment with better 
returns, avoidance of capital reversals from reduced reliance on funding outside the region, and 
reduction in the cost of financing and greater risk-sharing through greater pooling of funds. 
Nonetheless, deeper financial integration also has its vulnerabilities. One possible outcome of 
the eventual harmonization of cross-border financial market infrastructure and the proliferation 
of cross-border ownerships could be the ease and speed of the transmission of contagion 
across markets within the region. This could happen when enhanced synchronization in real

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The  proposed  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)  will  provide  a  quantifiable,  well 
informed, and balanced debate on regional economic integration among policy makers that 
aims to facilitate sustained growth and promote economic stability in the region. The outcome of 
the RETA is enhanced understanding and knowledge of the impact and magnitude of regional 
economic integration in Asia.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  A book shall be published which will comprise a collection of rigorous research papers 
suitable for journal publication. Each paper should draw on past ADB research and avoid 
duplication with existing papers. A summary of the findings shall be reflected in the overview or 
concluding  chapter.  The  methodology  section  should  clearly  explain  the  assumptions  and 
estimation techniques employed so as to facilitate independent replication and verification. 
Preliminary findings shall be presented in a midterm review workshop. Completion seminars 
shall be held for the final presentation of papers. 
 
12.  The project could cover, among other things, the following issues: 
 
(i)  Costs and benefits of FTAs. How well FTAs support trade and investment and 
boost economic growth as compared to other trade policy options; impacts on 
members versus nonmembers; distribution of costs and benefits, especially on 
smaller countries; and the effects of regional FTAs on globalization. 
 
(ii)  Impact  of  integrating  production.  Asian  economies  are  becoming  closely 
intertwined through trade and investment. Asia has also been a hub of global 
production  networks.  FDI  is  particularly  important  in  the  context  of  production 
networks.    The  trade–investment  nexus  and  technology  spillovers  between 
multinational corporations and domestic firms are often based on the form and 
strategy  of  FDI. Whether  FTAs  have  in fact facilitated  FDI  inflows  to  member 
countries, and whether this represents new investment (investment creation) driven 
by efficiency-seeking investment, or whether it is investment diversion driven by 
trade and/or investment preferences and tariff-jumping investment.  
 
(iii)  Costs  and  benefits  of  cross-border  transport  infrastructure.  The extent to 
which cross-border infrastructure projects covering different Asian regions have 
contributed  to  growth  and  poverty  reduction;  unequal  distribution  of  costs  and 
benefits across neighboring countries; and impacts of infrastructure development.  
 
(iv)  Costs and benefits of exchange rate policy coordination. Whether there is 
conclusive evidence to show exchange rate stability promotes trade and investment 
                                                
19 For Western Europe experience, see De Nicolo, G. and A. Tieman. 2006. Economic Integration and Financial 
Stability: A European Perspective. IMF Working Paper. WP/06/296.

5 
and contributes to higher growth; with monetary union, whether the cost of giving 
up independent monetary policy is more than the gain in joining a monetary union. 
 
(v)  Costs and benefits of deepening financial reforms and integration. Increased 
possibility and extent of financial contagion versus increased trade flows and trade 
integration; whether the proposed reforms reduce the cost of borrowing, diversify 
risks, and result in greater financial stability. 
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The RETA will cost an estimated $910,000 and is to be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s technical assistance (TA) funding program. The detailed cost breakdown and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA, with the Office of Regional Economic 
Integration implementing it in collaboration with departments concerned. The TA will require 
15.25  person-months  of  international  consulting  services,  16  person-months  of  national 
consulting services, and 1 person-month of resource persons’ services. All of the consultants 
will be engaged individually in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). Terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
The TA is expected to be completed in 12 months, from November 2008 to October 2009. 
 
15.  Eight international consultants will be engaged for a total of 12 person-months to write 
research papers that will comprise the eight main chapters of the book. They will be encouraged 
to take office in ADB for a week during the project to consult with Office of Regional Economic 
Integration staff and present their findings in completion seminars. A principal consultant will be 
hired for 2.25 person-months to produce a concluding or overview chapter summarizing the 
overall findings of the eight papers. As appropriate, an economics editor will also be engaged 
for approximately 1 person-month. 
 
16.  A midterm review workshop will be held once the draft studies are completed, where 
experts  will  be  invited  to  review  the  draft,  provide  comments,  or  recommend  revisions. 
Engagement of these resource persons as workshop discussants will total 1 person-month. 
After publication, a book launch will be organized to coincide with a regional forum, and the 
findings disseminated through the Asia Regional Integration Center website, among others. 
 
17.  One  national  consultant  will  be  engaged  for  12  person-months  to  serve  as  project 
coordinator for overall administration of the RETA. An events coordinator will be employed for 
1.5 person-months, intermittently, to serve as focal person for the conduct of the workshop and 
related activities. Once all the chapters of the book are complete, a copy editor will be hired for 
1.5 person-months and a typesetter for 1 person month to ensure a high-quality publication that 
adheres to ADB style, usage, and format is produced. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $910,000 on a grant basis for 
Quantifying  the  Costs and  Benefits  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  in  Asia,  and  hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Principal Consultant (international, 2.25 person-months) 
 
1.  The  principal  consultant  will  be  a  well-known  economist  with  proven  expertise  in 
economic analysis, and proven knowledge and extensive work experience on issues related to 
regional integration efforts in Asia or other regions. The consultant will preferably have adequate 
experience  in  similar  assignments  involving  the  preparation  and  coordination  of  research 
products and in working with international financial institutions. In consultation with Office of 
Regional Economic Integration (OREI) staff and the national consultant (project coordinator), 
the principal consultant will 
 
(i)  assist in preparing specific terms of reference for the various chapters of the 
book;  
(ii)  coordinate the work of the eight consultants responsible for the main chapters of 
the book, which will include reviewing the draft studies and suggesting revisions 
to these to ensure the studies form a consistent report; and 
(iii)  integrate  the  overall  findings  and  summarize  the  contents  of  the  different 
chapters in the overview or concluding chapter of the book. 
 
B.  Consultants for Research Papers (international, 12 person-months) 
 
2.  Eight international consultants will be engaged to write research papers that will cover 
the following topics: 
 
(i)  trade,  
(ii)  foreign direct investment,  
(iii)  monetary policy and exchange rate policies,  
(iv)  financial/capital markets, and  
(v)  cross-border infrastructure.  
 
3.  The consultants will be international experts with proven knowledge and extensive work 
experience  on  issues  related  to  regional  integration  efforts  in  Asia  or  other  regions.  The 
consultants  will  preferably  have  adequate  experience  in  similar  assignments  involving  the 
preparation and coordination of research products and in working with international financial 
institutions. 
 
4.  The consultants will, in coordination with OREI and the principal consultant, write their 
research papers and present these at the midterm review workshop, where resource persons 
will  be  invited  as  discussants.  The  researchers  will  incorporate  the  comments  from  the 
workshop and present their final drafts in completion seminars at Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) headquarters before submitting them to the principal consultant for consolidation. 
 
C.  Economics Editor (international, 1 person-month) 
 
5.  An economics editor with extensive experience in editing economic publications shall be 
engaged to ensure high-quality publication of the book that will be produced from the eight 
papers and the overview or concluding chapter.

1  0     Appendix 4 
D.  Consultants for Project Implementation (national, 16 person-months) 
 
6.  Project Coordinator. A project coordinator for overall administration of the regional 
technical assistance (RETA) shall be engaged for 12 person-months. The consultant should 
have adequate experience in coordination work, preferably in similar assignments involving 
economic publications. Familiarity with issues concerning regional economic integration in Asia 
will be an advantage. Under the supervision of OREI staff, this consultant will 
 
(i)  maintain communication with the international consultants and resource persons;  
(ii)  ensure the timely delivery of papers; 
(iii)  provide technical assistance in reviewing the papers prepared for the study; 
(iv)  guarantee smooth completion of the report and publication of the book; and  
(v)  oversee  the  organization  and  conduct  of  the  midterm  review  workshop, 
completion seminars, and book launch.  
 
7.  Events  Coordinator.  An  events  coordinator  will  be  engaged  for  approximately  1.5 
person months intermittently, to serve as overall coordinator of the midterm review workshop, 
completion seminars, and book launch. The events coordinator will have adequate experience 
in events management and will serve as the focal person in the preparation of administrative 
requirements  and  implementation  of  logistical  arrangements  for  the  workshop  and  related 
activities. 
 
8.  Copy Editor and Typesetter. A copy editor will be hired for 1.5 person-months to 
ensure that edited materials adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high publication 
standards, once all the chapters of the book are complete. In addition, a typesetter will be 
engaged for 1 person-month to lay out the text, tables, and charts of all the chapters of the book 
and convert the files into the required format for print publication. The consultants should 
possess  expertise  in  copy  editing  and  desktop  publishing,  and  preferably  have  extensive 
experience in similar assignments involving preparation of economic publications. 
 
E.  Resource Persons (international, approximately 1 person-month) 
 
9.  Resource persons, with background as policy makers and/or experts, will be engaged to 
review the draft chapters and participate as discussants in the midterm review workshop.
